summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney to Judge Alison J. Nathan, filed on July 2, 2021. The letter argues that the prosecution of Maxwell violates the Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA), drawing a parallel to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court's decision to vacate Bill Cosby's conviction due to a broken prosecutorial promise. The defense requests the dismissal of several counts in the indictment.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who authored and submitted this letter to the court, arguing for dismissal of charges based on the Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case, to whom this letter is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (S2 20 Cr. 330). The letter argues her prosecution violates an immunity agreement related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: William Henry Cosby Jr.
persons.context: Referenced as the defendant in Commonwealth of Pennsylvania v. William Henry Cosby Jr., whose conviction was vacated by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court due to a broken prosecutorial promise, which the letter uses as a legal analogy.

persons.name: Andrea Constand
persons.context: The individual who accused Bill Cosby of sexual assault in 2004 and later filed a civil suit against him, leading to the depositions where Cosby made inculpatory statements.

persons.name: Bruce Castor
persons.context: The former Montgomery County District Attorney who declined to prosecute Bill Cosby in 2005, issuing a statement the defense argues constituted a promise not to prosecute.

persons.name: Risa Veil Ferman
persons.context: The successor District Attorney who, ten years later, used Bill Cosby's civil deposition testimony to prosecute him for the same crimes.

connections.description: Everdell is submitting this legal letter on behalf of his client, Ghislaine Maxwell, arguing for the dismissal of charges against her.
The defense draws a direct legal parallel between Maxwell's situation (alleged violation of the Epstein NPA) and Cosby's situation (alleged violation of a prosecutorial promise).
Castor, as DA, made a promise not to prosecute Cosby, which Cosby relied upon, leading to his testimony in a civil deposition.
Ferman, as successor DA, prosecuted Cosby a decade later using the testimony he gave after Castor's promise.
Constand accused Cosby of sexual assault and filed a civil lawsuit against him.

events.title: Alleged Assault of Andrea Constand
events.description: Andrea Constand alleged that Bill Cosby sexually assaulted her at his residence.

events.title: Constand Reports to Police
events.description: Andrea Constand reported Bill Cosby's alleged conduct to the police approximately one year after the incident.

events.title: DA Castor Declines Prosecution
events.description: Then-District Attorney Bruce Castor determined there was insufficient evidence to charge Cosby and issued a public statement declining prosecution, which is later argued to be a binding promise.

events.title: Cosby's Civil Deposition
events.description: Believing he was immune from prosecution, Bill Cosby gave depositions in Andrea Constand's civil lawsuit, making inculpatory admissions.

events.title: Cosby's Criminal Prosecution and Conviction
events.description: Approximately ten years later, successor DA Risa Veil Ferman used Cosby's civil deposition admissions to prosecute and convict him for the same crimes.

events.title: Pennsylvania Supreme Court Vacates Cosby Conviction
events.description: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court vacated Bill Cosby's conviction, holding that DA Castor's promise was enforceable and the subsequent prosecution violated Cosby's Due Process rights.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense argues her prosecution violates the 'Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement' (NPA), which they claim granted her immunity.
The defense draws a direct legal analogy to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court's June 30, 2021, decision vacating Bill Cosby's conviction due to a broken prosecutorial promise.
The letter is a formal request to dismiss Counts One, Three, Five, and Six of the S2 Indictment against Maxwell.
The defense emphasizes that the Epstein NPA was a formal written agreement, which they argue makes their case for dismissal even stronger than the informal promise in the Cosby case.
The core legal principle invoked is that prosecutors must abide by their promises, and reneging on such agreements violates due process and fundamental fairness.
